Comments_List: I gained a lot of Constitutional knowledge and learned about the modalities and methods of deciding constitutional law
I learned a lot about Constitutional Law and how to "read like a lawyer."
I developed critical thinking and logical reasoning skills.
How to go about analysing the constitution. How to be proud, confident and self aware of my thoughts and ideas. How priviledged and thankful I am to be at Yale.

In this course I learned about what the Constitution itself says and how different courts/people have interpreted it over the years. In doing so, I also learned how to analyze and answer constitutional questions myself. This class was interesting in that it relied on textual analysis as well as social and political history to explain why different cases were decided in certain ways during different historical moments, beyond just what was written in the Constitution. I liked hearing about Professor Amar's experience, thought the TA's were incredible, and am glad I got this overview of constitutional law before graduating.
I learned more about the way that judges look at the law, particularly in regards to the Constitution.
Introduction to basic principles of constitutional interpretation, history of the founding & drafting of the Constitution

You gain a new appreciation for the nuances of American politics and law. Amar does a wonderful job weaving in the history and politics of each case. Beyond learning about the issues, you learn history, and you learn the relationships between the 3 branches.
Wow, what didn't I learn? This class had it all. Amar is the goat and haters are wack.
Most of all, I learned how to address scenarios from the perspective of a constitutional lawyer. I also gained a great deal of comfort reading case law.

Alright so here's the deal with ConLaw. You basically cover laws pertaining to the constitution (as the title suggests), such as McCulloch v. Maryland, Marbury v. Madison, etc, using certain "modalities" (structural, textual, historical, precendent, etc.). The class starts off pretty strong, but by the second half, lectures become pretty rambly. Prof. Amar is clearly very knowledgeable, but the way he lectures is not always that accessible. I will say though, this is a very good class to cr/d. Both the midterm and final are open notes, and besides that, you just have a short paper. On the other hand, if you really want to dive into the course, there's still a lot of depth to the case analyses.
The ability to analyze legal decisions and court cases for constitutional issues. Forced me to learn to read more selectively.
American constitutional history
An understanding of the Constitution, in particular how is affects federal (and state) law, the judiciary generally, and the overall structure of our government.
I learned principals of legal analysis, a lot about the history of american law, and how to analyze constitutional cases.

An extremely rewarding course when it comes to understanding the modalities of constitutional interpretation and the unique issues embedded within ongoing debates of abortion, affirmative action, etc.

An excellent introduction to the U.S. Constitution in a historical, political, and legal context. You learn how to analyze various constitutional issues, and develop a better understanding about the framework to one of the world's greatest democratic stories.
I learned how to analyze court cases and opinions by courts.
I learned a lot about the law and how to format a legal argument in this course. The course also taught me a lot about history and historical interpretation.
I learned so much from this course.  I learned how the system of constitutional law works and how to think about law.
This class is great if you do the readings and TAKE IT WITH THE SECTION!
I learned how to interpret court cases and make the strongest constitutional arguments using the Bobbit modalities.
This course provides a dive into a handful of key topics in constitutional lawfrom executive power to rightsthat are important for an informed student to know.
How to interpret the Constitution and how to understand issues in our daily life through that lens. Also how to read Supreme Court decisions.
I learned a lot about how the Constitution works, at more than just a surface level.

The goal of this course is specific: it aims to give its students a broad but comprehensive sense of the place of the American Constitution in our nation's history. It accomplishes this goal but goes beyond it. Students also get better at close reading, crafting arguments, thinking critically about history and culture, and just generally being responsible citizens.

How to look for and appreciate the historical subtleties of constitutional law

How to analyze constitutional law
Learn both an approach to con law and about many specific topics/cases in con law.
Great professor, great TA, great subject matter. Take the course.

I gained a solid foundation for understanding how to read the Constitution using tools of interpretation. In that way, I have been able to form my own thoughts regarding it and that is invaluable. It has made me a better citizen and American.
SO much about the constitution and how to apply constitutional thinking to the world
I learned how to analyze American constitutional law using Philip Bobbitt's modalities.

I learned how the Constitution affects everyones lives and how relevant it has been throughout history. I knew that the Constitution was important to the government and for our liberties, but it wasnt until this course that I realized how the Constitution has applied to situations in different ways just depending on who is on the court or what is going on in the country during that year. It was amazing to see how the document has developed into the rule of law that we abide to.
A strong foundation for understanding Constitutional Law.
A much more sophisticated understanding and deeper appreciation of the structure and history of U.S. government.  Plus skills in legal argumentation and in reading case law.

I learned a lot about the processes of constitutional decision-making, American history, and case law. I developed a series of lenses through which to view problems, and feel much more familiar with legal arguments.

I learned the basics of constitutional interpretation and a lot about the history of the Constitution and how the Supreme Court's jurisprudence in certain areas of the law has changed over time. This was a really good introduction to constitutional law and I'm told that Prof. Amar teaches it almost exactly the same way he teaches it at the law school. That does mean that we focused on certain areas of the law more than others--we talked a lot about the Reconstruction Amendments, Congress's Commerce Clause power and substantive due process. We also talked about separation of powers and executive privilege at the start of the course and about sex discrimination and the privacy line of cases towards the end of the course. I got a lot of practice reading Supreme Court opinions and getting an idea of the kinds of arguments that justices make. Another cool part of this class was that Amar would often talk about current constitutional law issues that came up in the news (of which there was a lot this semester) and give us his take.
I learned so much about constitutional law, but most of it I learned through section and doing the readings. If you do the readings, you will get so much out of this course.

I learned SO MUCH in this course about the Constitution and the American political system. Also about American history and lots of current issues, such as gerrymandering and supreme court nominations. I learned how to read and later to analyze court cases using the six modalities of constitutional interpretation, and to write about constitutional issues.
How to think critically about the Constitution.
I gained an understanding of the constitution and how it works, as well as how to think about things from a legal standpoint.
The ability to read and analyze court cases and gain a wide breadth of legal and political knowledge.
One of the few classes at yale that really digs into legal analysis!
You learn US constitutional law. I had a moderate background in the judicial system and I still learned a fair amount. A must-take for anyone at Yale.

This course allowed me to gain more experience with the US Constitution and the important historical contexts and cases which have shaped US federal legal history. This course was great for gaining an understanding of what the cases mean, but also their historical contexts and why they were decided in the manner that they were. Amar does a great job of bringing that context in, meaning that some of his arguments will differ from those found on Oyez or similar legal summaries.
Basis of Constitutional Law including important cases, theories, and the tools to form arguments about hypothetical cases.
How to interpret many cases and the constitution itself

The basics of constitutional law and how to make legal arguments. Also learned a lot about the political foundations of the United States and how the law interacts with other areas of government in different time periods.
I learned a ton about constitutional interpretation, constitutional structure, and constitutional history. I feel like I learned a ton about the context surrounding the constitution as well.
I have learned a new way of critical thinking and application of legal materials. As a prospective law student, I believe I gained a lot of skills from this class.
Through this course, I learned how to closely read Supreme Court cases, how to make logical legal arguments and to apply cases based on a set of issues.
We learned different modes of analyzing the Constitution and a lot more arcane history than was necessary.
A basic understanding of the constitution
I learned how to examine and discuss constitutional law cases and gained a new vocabulary for political science. I really feel like I now grasp how to begin to talk about constitutional law.
Good overview of US History and the thoughts that went into writing law.
This class is a great introduction into the world of constitutional law. It is a must take for anyone interested in law school.

I learned how to use the Bobbit modalities when examining a Constitutional argument, and learned so much about the multidimensional character of the constitutional decisions that surround us in the news.
A bucketload of history, political science, and law--both theory and application. This course gives you the opportunity to not just learn about law, but to actually do it.

I learned how to read opinions by Justices and analyze constitutional issues, contextualizing opinions through the lens of history. I learned a TON about American history and the transformation of the Constitution over the country's lifespan.
I gained a broad understanding of the constitution and its role in the legal history of the United States

In this course, we learned about various methods of interpreting constitutional law. We looked at canonical Supreme Court cases throughout American history, as well as some Presidential veto messages, etc. that pertained to constitutional law. We explored how the court's understanding of constitutional law has evolved over generations, and how best to apply constitutional arguments to novel cases (which made up the majority of exam questions too). We left the course more able to cite cases regarding the Constitution, but more importantly, we left able to create our own constitutional arguments after learning how to do so.
I gained a working knowledge of "classic" Court cases in Constitutional law & a more nuanced understanding of American history.

By taking this course, I learned how to use different modalities to interpret the constitution and laws/actions that might violate parts of the constitution. This course gives you a great foundation in reading case law and a strong understanding of many big name cases that are referred to in debates surrounding the Constitution.

Learning the various modalities of constitutional interpretation; making constitutional arguments using SCOTUS doctrines, modalities, and legal analysis; gaining a historical review of U.S constitutional history
I learned how to analyze cases using the Constitution and case precedent. I learned a lot about US constitutional jurisprudence!

This was a challenging but really great class, very rewarding especially. I learned how to critically think about the constitution, and apply constitutional law to historical, and contemporary events. Especially pertinent in current political climate! It also gave me some direction in terms of my future career/education-- wether you like this class is a good indication if you will enjoy law school. Also gives you a semi chronological history of rights movements, beginning with abolition through LGBTQ rights in the constitution. Hit all the major con law cases. By the end of the course I felt extremely competent in my ability to apply the constitution and make judgements on the constitutionality of anything thrown my way. I feel like i really got a ton out of this class, well worth the work!

I gained a deep knowledge of both the history of the US and the formation of the American Constitution but also about historical cases based on constitutional law. I gained the skills for textual analysis of the constitution to apply it to the law.

This is America 101. As an international student, I have often been lost in political discussion. Who is the Senate? Who is the House? What does the executive order do? This class answers all those questions, and more.

Constitutional law from the founding to the present day. Through Supreme Court cases, we examined the powers of the 3 government branches, voting rights, slavery and race and sex equality and abortion rights. I learned how to think about constitutional issues and apply relevant tests.

I learned important information about the history of the constitution, the contents of the document, and how legal analyses are conducted in order to understand why provisions are or are not constitutional.
This class gave me a general overview of issues in con law and an understanding of various ways to address these issues.
I developed knowledge about the Constitution and the history of Constitutional case law, and I developed skills in practicing and applying Constitutional law.
I learned about the history of constitutional law in the US, the importance of the Constitution to American democracy, and how to interpret the modalities of law.

I was introduced to legal thinking and analysis and learned about the history of the Constitution and constitutional decision-making in the United States that is extremely relevant to our country's history and current events. I learned how to read cases and how to interpret and write about issues within a constitutional framework.
gained an understanding of constitutional rights, important legal cases, and American constitutional history. I also learned how to use various legal reasoning skills to make an argument.

I really enjoyed Con Law. I left this course with a new understanding of constitutional happenings throughout the United States and a deeper understanding of constitutional modalities. I would definitely recommend taking Con Law if you want a much more developed understanding of the American Constitution and democracy, too.

This class gave me a deeper understanding of the constitution, how and why it was created, and how it has been applied throughout American history. Through a unique approach to constitutional study, this course focused on the history and structure of the document.

I learned about the history, text, and interpretation of the constitution. I learned how constitutional interpretation has changed over time, how a lawyer analyzes the constitution, and Amars philosophy on how the constitution is rightly interpreted. The exams taught me to spot legal issues.

The content was interesting, and the cases that we read were important to understanding the basics of constitutional law. Lectures were unorganized, which meant that Professor Amar spent a disproportionate amount of time on one or two cases and did not cover a majority of reading material, despite the fact that the cases he missed or skimmed over were important to the course.

The strengths of the course are its relevance to current events, Amar and the TFs, and the breadth of material covered.

Weakness: Toward the end of the course, there's too much reading assigned. Perhaps it could be streamlined. Not much of it is covered in class, so it's superfluous rather than helpful.

The Teaching Fellows are vital to this course.  They are wonderful.  Professor Amar is a brilliant historian, and cares very deeply about the course and the students, but his lectures were often confusing or difficult to follow.  I wish he would outline some sort of structure for each lecture.

Strengths:
-Amar's lectures
-TA quality
-assessment formats

Weakness:
-too many readings. Honestly, no one does any of the readings outside of the case book, and in the second half of the semester too many readings in the case book alone are assigned

Strength: the professor and the TA's.

Weakness: not enough feedback on examinations.

I think lectures sometimes went off on tangents and got kind of hard to follow, and then at other times we seemed to move through cases really quickly and had to wait for section to really go over them. But Professor Amar's passion for the material was clear and lectures were usually engaging. I think the syllabus could have been organized a bit better because it wasn't typically clear what we needed to have read on a weekly basis, but now that the semester is over I understand the thematic flow of the material.

Strengths: interesting historical perspective, TAs are amazing
Weaknesses: lectures are all over the place, not much gained from going to class, most of the learning comes from section
Excellent course, as always

Strength: Amar is an unbelievable lecturer who really knows his stuff. The TA's are excellent. The discussion sections are really helpful and TAs clear up what you need to know. GO TO SECTION! 
Weaknesses: In an effort to keep lectures "ripped from the headlines" Amar often goes off topic. He spent a couple lectures talking about Kavanaugh, which was not particularly constructive. He doesn't follow the structure of the syllabus perfectly and sometimes is hard to follow (if you haven't done the readings carefully). But theres a ton of reading and that happens. Use your TAs to clear up the questions you have following lectures.
You learn so much!

Lectures often derailed, and the last few units of the course were compressed into an uncomfortably short time frame. I wish less time was spent on the more foundational units of the course, and more on the later units  especially because the later units required much more reading.

Strengths:
Amar's a big deal, and he knows it, and he acts like it.
The TAs are amazing and they're the best law school students at YLS and that is an impressive statement.
It's absurdly relevant. From the Nixon cases (Trump), appointment power cases (Kavanaugh hearings - oh, he testified there by the way), presidential power (Muslim ban executive order), to NFIB v. Sebelius (the Obamacare/Affordable Care Act case -- oh, and this week some Texas judge just ruled the ACA unconstitutional), and more, it will absolutely be one of if not the most relevant to real political life classes you ever take.
The lunches he goes with students to are 10/10. Actually go. Guests drop in. Big time guests. Like the CEOs of elite law firms, professors at YLS, top policy aides, and Evan Wolfson (one of if not the most influential figures in the nationwide legalization of gay marriage) just drop in on occasion. It's worth it.
The actual stuff you read is a LOT if you actually read it all but the vast majority of it is very interesting. 

Weaknesses:
Amar's a big deal, and he knows it, and he acts like it.
There is an obscene amount of reading. It's essentially impossible to do it all -- that try hard, YLS-or-bust kid you know? They won't read it all. 
Amar assigns 5 of his own books. You for sure have to purchase the casebook (~$275 I wanna say), the others you should just rent, but honestly you truly only need to read the casebook, America's Unwritten Constitution, and America's Constitution: A Biography. I wouldn't even rent the others, and instead purchase AUC/ABAC and annotate them.
It was perfect

The TAs are incredible! Soren's section is where I really digested and understood the material, and meeting with him throughout the semester allowed me to ask questions and dive deeper into the material. This is what made the course worthwile.

Prof. Amar cares about teaching and his students a lot and is a passionate lecturer. However, often his passion for the materials occludes the content as his lectures jump around. It doesn't help that the readings are blocked weeks at a time, and so it's hard to know what readings to do for which class. I know Prof. Amar adapts the timeline of the course to current events etc, however it would be helpful if he posted online a more detailed reading schedule that he kept up to date.

Strength: You will really learn a lot. The exams almost become enjoyable if you know your stuff and are interested in the subject.

Weaknesses: This is not truly an accessible course. @FGLI students -- beware that the books Amar asks you to buy for this course are not cheap. I think it is also disingenuous for the course to pretend that all the books are required. Frankly, the casebook is the only thing you need.
This is a phenomenal course as is. More instruction on how to prepare for examinations, however, could perhaps better facilitate learning for students.

Akhil Reed Amar is an interesting lecturer, and he knows it. He isn't afraid to assert his legal opinion, and his general opinion for that matter. I thought a weakness was the sheer volume of reading which very few students could keep up with (and I mean VERY few).

There should really be slides or something for lecture. Amar would often ramble and it was very difficult to keep track of what he was saying and whether it was relevant or not. Also, the amount of reading expected of students is absolutely absurd - the only way someone could accomplish it is if they had no other commitments.
The course is amazing, however the grading scheme is a bit overwhelming with the final accounting for 60% of your grade.

The lectures were very engaging, but they were quite disconnected from the exams.  Everything we learned in lecture was helpful to the exam, and everything we read was helpful to the exam, but there was no guidance as to how to approach the exam unless you attended the optional review sessions.  There was also no standardized guidance for the paper - luckily, my TF was very helpful about the paper once you had an idea, but there was no guidance as to where to begin.

GO TO SECTION
The class would be better if there was section then lecture. The section tells you what the case is about, lecture gives you ways to think about it. With the lecture first, you end up missing a lot of Amar's brilliant points.
The discussion section, being complimentary to lecture discussions and providing clarity for the material covered during lecture, aided in learning constitutional law.

Strengths: The TFs are dedicated to teaching students and as law students, are very familiar with the work.

Weaknesses: Amar's lectures are very unstructured. I've had problems keeping up what he was saying because most of it is stream of consciousness. He really provided historical oversight while my TF taught me the cases.

Strengths: The sheer amount of reading means we learn a lot about constitutional law. I definitely know more than I did a semester ago about constitutional principles, the powers of each branch, and the constitutional take hot topic issues like abortion and affirmative action. 

Weaknesses: The reading often felt overwhelming, and in retrospect, not all of it was necessary. Also, I firmly believe that only attending lecture (and not section) would make this class impossible; I don't think the lecture on its own can prepare someone for the course.
It is really disorganized at times, and there is a huge discrepancy between sections and how the TAs grade
Great course.

The material was amazing, I feel like I will be a better citizen for having taken this course!  A weakness was the reading load - it was intense.  I believe that the course would be served better by reduced readings (so that deeper thought could take place on the topics covered).
Super interesting lectures, well-run sections, and enjoyable exams. One weakness may be the sudden increase in pace after the midterm, but otherwise great.

This was a great course. I LOVED going to section it really helped to clarify things that were ambiguous in lecture. My biggest complaint is that lecture tended to be VERY scattered and it was really hard to take notes because there were so many tangents that it was hard to follow the main point of what was going on. (Why section was SO important)
I thought this course was fantastic. Professor Amar is a brilliant lecturer, who presents the course material clearly. I cannot think of any ways the course could be improved.
I appreciated Professor Amar involving current events into the lecture when a big event had occurred.

The underlying material is very good and some lectures are fantastic, but others get extremely repetitive, which results in us speeding through some parts of the syllabus and spending far too much time on others
Amar has it down.

I think one major strength of this course are the TAs. You really learn the most in section, since they actually break down cases in a way that's understandable. However, if you don't have a good TA, you have a much worse experience. One weakness of the course are lectures. Although Professor Amar is clearly a well-respected legal expert, his lectures are unorganized and full of grandstanding and barely disguised elitism. Another major strength of this course is the content. It is really engaging and covers a spectrum of constitutional issues.

Prof. Amar is a great lecturer and that was a big strength of the course. I thought that he made going to class super interesting, and the syllabus was constructed so that we talked about some pretty interesting cases and aspects of the Constitution. I also liked that Prof. Amar gave a lot of historical and political context for some of the cases because I think that definitely helps you understand them and their impact. Personally I found the readings really interesting and genuinely enjoyed reading all of the opinions, and the lectures definitely helped me see their most important parts and think about the arguments that the justices were making critically and in the context of past precedent and what further implications their reasoning would have for later cases. 

I can't speak for other sections, but my TA was really good and super great about meeting with us outside of class if we had questions or wanted to talk about anything law-related, so the fact that section wasn't a drag was another plus about the course. There was one required paper and an optional final paper (in addition to the exams) and we were given a lot of freedom in choosing what to write about.

Also, Amar holds weekly lunches in a dining hall after class and I would definitely recommend going to them. I certainly didn't agree with Amar about everything he said and he's definitely a pretty opinionated person, but he's also very influential in the realm of constitutional law and it was nice that he made himself available to us and was happy to answer more questions so I think it's worth taking advantage of that. 

As for weaknesses, I do think that we spent a little too much time on some of the Civil War-era cases and the Youngstown/Civil War distinction because this was something that Amar just got really excited about and wanted to make sure he drove home. I think this meant that we were a little rushed towards the end of the course, even though we were mostly on track with the syllabus for most of the semester, so we didn't get to spend quite as much time on some of the affirmative action, sex discrimination and privacy cases that came up towards the end. We also had the sexual orientation line of cases on the syllabus but barely talked about them in class at all. Overall, though, we spent a lot of time on different things and got a great overview to a few really important areas of constitutional law, even if an intro course like this can't be fully comprehensive.

Strengths: Amar makes an effort to talk about current events that relate to constitutional law, the cases are very interesting and well laid out

Weaknesses: SO much reading, Amar does not talk that much about the cases themselves and so it is sometimes hard to appreciate the nuances when he assumes we have foundational knowledge that many of us lacked

Sections are absolutely amazing, and they were the best part of the class, particualrly if you did all the reading. 
Professor Amar was the weakness of this course, particualrly in his uncomfortable combative lectures on contemporary politics (I walked out because I was uncomfortable in a lecture he spent most of the time speaking of Kavanaugh during). He also lectured in a slightly disorganized manner, but was generally engaging otherwise.

Strengths: Akhil Reed Amar is brilliant, engaging, and wise, and it's a privilege to take his class. His lectures are reason enough to take this class even if you aren't interested in pursuing a career related to law or politics. (If you are, it's a must-take!)
Weaknesses: The readings for this class are ridiculously dense and lengthy, so you have to be strategic about which cases or parts of cases you read. Amar doesn't really engage with you on this, of course, but you can ask your TA how to identify what's critical and just focus on those cases.
I think the course would be fine with  less reading.
Its up to the student to do the readings. that defines the class. It works for some, but not so much for other. Very easy to fall behind on.

Amar's lectures are all over the place. He goes on long tangents, but once you understand his style the lectures are very enjoyable. I did the vast majority of my learning in section (which is essential) and attended lecture to enjoy Amar's tirades. Strengths are definitely the YLS Section TFs, and Amar's general enthusiasm for the content.

The best part of this course was the sections. I was taught by Benjamin Hand who was a fantastic teacher. My recommendation would actually be to increase section length.

The main weakness of this class is professor Amars lecture style. He lectures are very unstructured, rambling, and hard to follow. I have a lot of respect for his knowledge of the subject, but I think more can be done to improve the communication of that knowledge to students.

This course does a good job of introducing people to how to read a case, with Amar spending a couple of lectures going through McCulloch v. Maryland in order to spell out how cases should be read. The course does have a lot of reading, but in general its not difficult to gain the understanding of the cases from skimming the cases rather than doing all of the required reading. It would be more helpful in class if a bit more attention could be paid to the important sections of the cases, rather than just diving in immediately to the context and deeper reasoning, as at times it would be confusing where Amar had intended to take the lecture having not had the same background and foresight into the material as him. In addition, while I appreciated how Amar would tie in current events, he did spend a very solid amount of time talking about his opinions on the Kavanaugh hearings (which in it of themselves I didn't mind hearing, but it did take about 1-1.5 classes to get through his thoughts), which then took time away from other material (like covering Korematsu, for instance).
Lectures could be more organized

The strengths are that lectures were always eye-opening and fascinating with section being one of my favorite portions of the class due to the fact that a lot of the discussions and cases were clarified during that time. One weakness is that the professor spent uneven amounts of time going over the cases so we understood some concepts extremely thoroughly and well while others were briefly mentioned in section or not discussed at all, resulting in a lot of self studying for both exams.

Strengths - great lectures, great discussion sections and super interesting material
Weaknesses - somewhat confusing syllabus: we werent always exactly sure what readings we would be covering in lecture
I think the course could be better structured and balanced. It gets really heavy at the end

This is a really wonderful course in all respects. Amar is a very engaging professor who didn't shy away from difficult current topics in Constitutional Law. The one weakness of this class are the readings--there's simply too much to read and not enough time. I found myself frequently needing to look up synopses of cases, and often didn't read the secondary sources.

Strengths - Extremely competent people teaching the section who were clear and concise instructors. Give em a hand. Amar seemed to very rarely teach Con Law, however, choosing instead to rhapsodize on American history or exceptionalism rather than anything else.
TAs are great. Akhil Amar is singularly awful.
This course is great! The lectures get a little rambling, and the reading is a lot to keep up with.

The response paper is a big weakness: It needs to be made clear how this will be graded. I was told that it was "low-key" and just a "general reaction to whatever we wanted," by my TA. A few of my friends reported the same thing. The grading on the response paper was harsh. I wish that would've been more clear, and I would have put much more effort into it.

The course definitely had a lot of reading and was heavier towards the end. Sometimes Professor Amar went on tangents but in general the lectures were interesting. But the real gem of this course is section. Travis was an amazing TA and section was great for ironing out the concepts of the course.
This course was excellent, and I appreciated the intuitive approach to Constitutional Law.

Lectures can be a little hard to follow and there is far too much reading. I think having a good section/TA is key to enjoying the course and effectively synthesizing the mass of information it throws at you. Fortunately, I had an incredible TA, and as far as I can tell Professor Amar chooses his TAs well.

This course covered so much material in one semester. We started very slowly, which I think was a good thing, learning to analyze Supreme Court cases and getting used to applying the right frame of reference to best understand constitutional issues and make arguments. The weakness is that it was sometimes difficult to follow where we were in the course because it moved fast and we would occasionally get sidetracked in lectures; we might have tried to cover too much material. However I found these detours very interesting, which is why i think the material on the syllabus should be pared down instead. I found that there was significant mismatch between what we would talk about in lectures and what we should up on the exams.

The strengths of this course are really Amar and the TAs. They were all excellent and very knowledgeable and willing to help.

Professor Amar is excellent and he should just keep doing his thing, but more time could be spent on the historical context of the cases. Also, at times the course moved too slow (especially at the beginning) but the second half of the course was pretty rapid.

The course is relatively well organized into discrete sections of constitutional law. The optional section is essential to understanding the cases discussed, especially when the speed of the course picks up and we can't get to them all in lecture. The tests are kind of fun, honestly -- they are issue spotters, requiring you to pick up on previously discussed constitutional issues in novel situations. The grading is mostly fair.

However, the reading load is often overbearing, so if you plan to read each individual case in its entirety and really delve into the depths of constitutional law, get ready for some long nights. luckily, online resources exist to help you get the general gist, which should be enough to get you by in the class. It just depends what you're looking for: a deep understanding of constitutional law, or a decent grade in the class. Additionally, Professor Amar's lectures are often confusing and lack structure. He frequently goes on long, unrelated tangents or simply doesn't discuss the readings or constitutional law at all. It's hard to follow along with where we are in the syllabus, or what we're supposed to have read. There is no powerpoint or anything like that, so it's difficult to understand what the most important concepts are to take away from the class. Additionally, Amar sometimes says kind of problematic things (this year, mainly regarding the accusations against Supreme Court Justice Brett Kavanaugh or racial tensions) and gets really aggressive when challenged on them. This was kind of upsetting to a lot of students, especially many women and POC, and made a collaborative, productive learning experience difficult for many.

The lectures are by far the best part of the class. I learned so much from Professor Amar--he challenges the liberal orthodoxy on a number of issues, and always has great hot takes. I find myself wanting to ask him questions about controversial topics when they come up in the news. He brings clarity and lots of context to every issue. Because lectures were so important for me, I wish there were a way to separate the laptop note takers from the non laptop note takers, a la Psych and the Good Life. It was very distracting to see my peers surfing the internet during the lecture.

The lectures for this course can be rather boring as Professor Amar tends to go on tangents that don't relate to the course and he's not always the most engaging lecturer. That being said, if you take this course, treat the sections as the course and the lectures as the supplements because the TAs do a much better job of walking you through the cases whereas lecture gives you a sort of historical overview (sometimes).

Strengths: a wide array of materials; gaining a new perspective of history 

Weakness: lecture is badly designed to prepare students for exams; sections are very popular but should be mandatory; there should be a better/more structured  curriculum to teach the skills necessary for the exams

Section was beyond helpful to understanding the course material. But sometimes the exams felt tangential to the course material because you just might have focused your studying on areas that did not appear on the issue spotters.

The quantity of reading is very overwhelming, so i ended up barely reading. I did well in the class nonetheless because he goes over a lot in lecture, but I wish I had more time to engage with the texts. Overall, there is so much content so sometimes it did feel like we spent too little time on important themes.
The main strength is the section. I have learned so much from those intimate discussions. The weakness is the cost of the textbooks - it is way too high.

Strengths: Brilliant TAs and Professor teaching you top-notch constitutional arguments. It brings in history and political science for a more well-rounded understanding of the political instruments. The take-home element of the test takes off the pressure for rote memory. 

Weaknesses: If you choose to do all the readings and the research paper, the workload is heavy.

The discussion sections were absolutely invaluable to go over lecture material. The lectures were quite informative and interesting but at times it felt like Amar was spending too much time reviewing material from the previous lecture. He also got off the schedule, which made it even more difficult to try to keep up with the reading. The reading that we were assigned was barely manageable in the beginning of the course and frankly became impossible. Indeed, the casebook reading by itself was substantial, with the additional books by Prof. Amar difficult to find time for. I would be very interested to know how many people did all of just the casebook reading, and I bet it is very few. The readings can and should be less, more targeted to what we cover in lecture.

S: open note/book exams, very fair assignments
W: syllabus was hard to follow in terms of knowing what each class was going to address, some classes seemed to me more of extended tangents that did not relate to the topic at hand
Lecture often failed to cover crucial information needed for Constitutional analysis and exams.

The strengths of this course are the lectures, the TAs, and the course organization. The weaknesses are that the reading is too overwhelming and not always aligned with what is tested or studied in class.
I think that the course does a great job of presenting cases thematically, but I think that some cases should be given more attention than they were in class.

This course introduced me to a legal and constitutional way of thinking that I was not used to and forced me to grow and apply this knowledge myself. However, I thought that the lectures sometimes were too repetitive and focused too heavily on tangents instead of the cases themselves. And, since Professor Amar only assigned books that he had written, we were exposed to very few opinions and interpretations of the Constitution outside of Professor Amar's own, which is not ideal for an introductory course.
Less time on the beginning stuff, more time on the ending stuff!

strengths: section, YLS TAs
weaknesses: lecture can sometimes be confusing and poorly organized

Lecture is interesting, but often feels kind of off the wall. I think the biggest weakness of the class is how little it feels like an *intro* course; Amar should be doing a small lecture about his interpretations of the Constitution, not offering his opinions as a base for students' engagement with the document.

Strengths: Amars sweeping and clever lectures, very knowledgeable and accomplished TAs, and a sense that you are fulfilling your civic duty by understanding our government and judicial system. Ties to current events and enhances students understanding of the U.S political system. Weaknesses: The course should give more information about the midterm before the exam. Sample answers to past exams would be extremely helpful. Despite attending the review sessions and listening to TAs advice, I had little sense of what the midterm would require before taking it.

Professor Amar holds some interesting views on the Constitution, which he gets across in the first few lectures. The course quickly deteriorates after that, however, and lectures become semi-structured ramblings. Take it if you're interested in constitutional law, but otherwise I would just audit the first few weeks of the class.

This is a quintessential Yale course for a reason. If the subject material interests you, you should take it. But only if you have the time and energy to really dig in to the material -- otherwise, you will not get as much out of it.
Definitely! Take the section and keep up on the reading if you're taking it for a grade. If you're taking it for Credit, absolutely take the section as well.

As a senior, I can say this was one of my favorite classes at Yale. The subject matter itself is fascinating, and learning from Professor Amar was truly a privilege. I recommend taking the section, as my TA Travis was excellent, and because it does a good job of focusing on the information on which you may actually be assessed. In my experience, the grading has been fair. Exams are flexible- you can either take a short or long version, depending on your preferred assessment method. The workload for the exams and essay is relatively light; however, there are a LOT of readings. I think this course is ideal for sophomores and juniors- I wish I had taken it earlier, as I probably would have applied to law school, but c'est la vie. In short, this course has revolutionized how I think about constitutional law and caused me to want to become a judge one day. Take it!
Yes! Great material, professor, and pace. One of the best classes I have taken. P Amar plants a sense of great civic duty and responsability in you. That is an important thing to teach.

I would recommend this course to pretty much everyone. Even if you're not interested in American history or going to law school, if you live in this country and follow politics at all it provides a really helpful overview about how court cases are decided and what some of the most influential ones have taught us. It's a fine credit/d option because it is hard to keep up with all of the reading but easy to learn and appreciate the material just by going to lecture and section. Some of the work is optional, as is section, but you should definitely enroll in a section if you take the class because the TAs are incredible and basically break down the lecture material so that you can really understand the big takeaways from each week.

I took the class CR/D, which was a good call in that lectures are completely disorganized and you're responsible for your own learning. Not sure if I would recommend to other students as the lectures were not very compelling.
I would recommend this course to another student. It was interesting and Professor Amar does a good job of engaging the students.

Absolutely. Con Law is one of those "must take" courses at Yale. Professor Amar is a quirky but brilliant professor who clearly loves what he does, and his lectures were always interesting and engaging. Con Law is an easy class to take Cr/D and avoid the readings, but I think the casebook readings are actually well structured and written. That said, it is incredibly easy to fall behind on the readings. Workload is manageable- midterm with take-home option, 5-page response paper, final with take-home option, and an optional paper. The personality cult that forms around Professor Amar is a bit weird, but he and the TAs for the course are easily accessible. Take the class!

Absolutely! Take it for sure. If you can and want to, make sure you have time after class on monday to go to lunches with Prof. Amar. I had a class directly after and regret not being able to spend lunches learning more from him.
Hey Prof. Amar, Stop defending Kavanaugh

If you are sure you are interested in con law, take this. If you are not, you will likely get lost and have trouble focusing. There is a lot of material and a very thick list of readings that you need to actually do.
Yes, essential.
Yes. However, I would make sure to recommend opting into the optional section  without the section, the course is less helpful.

At the very minimum, this is a class you basically MUST Credit/D at some point. It's super easy to just pass. Seriously. It's not super easy to make an A. Amar is a fantastic lecturer, the topic is exceedingly relevant 25/8, the optional section and TAs are great, it's possible to do relatively little reading and do well in the class. A good outline (read: Excel/Sheets file with every major case and a sentence or two describing them) is ESSENTIAL for the midterm/final. It's genuinely a class that will make you more knowledgeable about how our society functions -- even international students and students who don't plan to live in the U.S. will benefit.
Absolutely - must take at Yale
Yes  it will help you understand the U.S. government much better. Section is particularly helpful.

Take this course! Don't drive yourself crazy doing all the readings, rent the casebook on amazon, and do the casebook readings. You will be fine in the class and get a ton out of it without making it anxiety inducing.

I would certainly recommend this course to another student, but do not have too high hopes for Prof. Amar -- the magic is in the TF you choose. Frankly, Amar was insufferable this semester at points with all of his tangential hot takes about Brett Kavanaugh. 

All that said, you will learn A LOT. Be prepared to handle high volumes of readings -- nearly 300 pages for some lectures. The second half of lecture is definitely more rigorous than the first.

Take it once you've settled into Yale College (I took it as a first year and was very intimidated)! It's a great course to take if you want to go into anything that requires legal study, but definitely know what you're getting into!

I think the content of the course was really interesting, however I found myself frustrated with Amar and his teaching style. Lectures were a hodge-podge of information delivered in a jumbled manner. He doesn't have slides so if you zone out for even 5 seconds you will be completely lost. It's also very difficult to understand what is important to know from lecture and what isn't. If I'm being honest I would say its not worth it to go to lecture.

If you do take the class DEFINITELY sign up for section (even if you Cr/D) that's where I learned the content. Crazy amount of reading, but you don't need to do all of it. Very easy to pass.
I would highly recommend this course to any student interested in law or United States history. Definitely the best lecture the PLSC department has to offer.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student who is interested in law.  If you're interested in logic, history, language, etc., and want to learn more about law, then you will LOVE this course.  If you don't care about law, aren't detail-oriented, think parsing language and trains of logic is a waste of time, then you will  hate this course.  I guess that's pretty self-explanatory from the course's title.  Be prepared to put in a lot of time and effort, but it very much be worth it.
Absolutely. You really need to do the reading though and go to section if you want to learn. But for the amount of work I did, I learned more than any other class i've taken at yale.
The course provides massive insight on the Constitution and the cases surrounding it.

Neither yes nor no. Take it if you want to learn about constitutional law, are ready to engage with the reading materials, and will be excited to build a strong relationship with your TF. Prof. Amar knows a lot of history and his lectures can be interesting, but we only learned about 30% of the cases we needed to know in lectureso be ready to engage in a lot of studying on your own. If you're interested in the material, this can be fun! But if you don't do the readings, be warned about the results. You will not learn everything you need to know in class.

Take this class! Professor Amar rambles a bit in lecture, but the sections are really fun. Make sure you do the reading though, because it is really easy to get behind and then lost, especially towards the end of the semester when there's a lot more cases per week.

I'm not sure. The amount of reading made this class worth it, but also was very stressful. It took me a very long time to read a small amount of readings, and until reading period, I was 500-1000 pages behind in reading. I also thought Professor Amar's lecture style was very hard to learn from.

Not as highly as most students do. I was really excited about it going into the semester, but I found the lectures disorganized and difficult to follow at times. Also I noticed that people were graded very differently depending on whether or not they are in a section.

Yes, but only if you plan to go to section and really engage with the readings and the assignments. If you do, you'll learn a ton; if not, you'll enjoy the theatrical entertainment of Akhil Amar's storytelling and maybe learn something about constitutional ethos but you'll get much less out of it.
Yes, Amar is great, would definitely recommend.
Yes, I think that this course makes you a better citizen!

Yes. The readings were INTENSE -- If you read all textbook excerpts and all of the secondary source books, you would have spent 2-3 hours per day reading. This would not have included making notes, review, or other studying exercises. 

Yet, it seems like it was all worth it. I did not do all the readings, but I think I made it through with decent performance. 

Amar is a great professor and it will be one of your most memorable Yale courses if you take it, guaranteed.

Yes, but only because of the TAs. Professor Amar is clearly an incredible scholar but does not know how to lecture or organize a course. The exams were the best I have ever taken--extraordinarily well written.
Yes, absolutely. This helps inform the way you view history, the present, and everything else. It is so important.

Yes. I would recommend this course to another student because you learn so much and it changes how you think about things. All of what you learn is applicable to present day politics which makes engaging in the material really fun.
This class was only easy to understand because of my TA
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Even if you are not interested in constitutional law, you should take this course just to become a more informed global citizen.
I would recommend this course to anyone because of how important the Constitution is in everyones life.

Yes if you're interested in American history and the origination of our laws. It's possible to do well in the course with very little effort, but much more enjoyable if you engage with the cases assigned.
An understanding of the Constitution is vital for our society. Take this course.

This course is incredible.  I highly recommend it.  You should feel comfortable taking it for a letter grade if you're willing to invest the time/effort in doing the readings.  But even if you just take it Cr/D/F (if knowing this makes you feel more confident: it's very easy this way), Con Law is an absolutely wonderful learning experience and will contribute substantially to the quality of your liberal education.

I would recommend this course to another student, but go to section!!! That is where you really learn Con Law. Also, don't be afraid to challenge Amar's ideas. He is very smart, but treats his own opinions as objective facts and more students should challenge that.

ABSOLUTELY! This was my favorite class that I have taken at Yale so far and I enjoyed it from start to finish. I think some of this is personal preference since it turned out that I just really enjoyed reading the court opinions and thinking about how they all fit together to form the court's jurisprudence. But I would recommend it to anyone interested in American politics because it gives you another perspective from which to think about policy decisions, as well as a perspective on the interplay between courts and policymakers over America's history. If you know you're interested in the law or in America's judiciary  at all then it's definitely a great course to take. Amar is a really good teacher and his lectures are really engaging, so even if you don't agree with him about everything you can still learn a lot from him (it also makes sense to understand what his views are because he's so well-known in the field). I know that a lot of people take this course credit/D because there's so much reading, so I think that could be one way to go if you're concerned about it, but I didn't think it had as heavy a workload as that reputation implies. The readings can be time consuming if you do them all, but outside of the readings there were just two exams and one paper (plus an optional paper) to worry about. On way or the other, take it for sure because it's a really cool Yale experience to take advantage of and it'll teach you a lot about a subject that is super relevant to understanding U.S. politics on a deeper level!
Definitely. It is incredibly useful and if you actually put the work in, you will get so much out.

I would recommend this to course to someone who wants to do the casebook reading and engage in the course. It was very fulfilling to really engage with the material (and immensely helped during Amar's disorganized lectures).

Take this class if you are at all interested in law or politics or if you want to learn from THE leading constitutional scholar! It's a privilege just to take this class; Amar is brilliant and has tons and tons of valuable insights to offer about everything from Lincoln to the Civil Rights Movement to present supreme court nominations (although his opinions on current issues can be controversial, he's so smart, it's worth listening and forming your own opinions).
Maybe. It's a lot of reading, but not actually that hard. Amar is a legend, and very smart, but very opinionated.

Knowing about our constitution and how the cases regarding it have led to the way our nation and its legal system works today is important for any student. The course is constantly engaging and interesting, and though it's a lot of reading, you can easily pick and choose what to read. I took the course Credit/D/fail, and I was able to learn a lot while only doing the readings that interested me.
If interested in case law, this course is essential.
Yes, if you have any interest in law or legal history.
A must take. Seriously. At a minimum audit/credit/d this class.

Definitely one of the must-take courses if you are interested in politics, political science, of if you've wanted to learn more about the Constitution and constitutional law. You will like your TA more than Amar, but Amar nevertheless is a great storyteller and has the memory to really incorporate a variety of contexts to the material at hand. Definitely has potential to be a good 5th class or Credit/D class, but keep in mind that there are a lot of cases to go through, but they're worth it if you enjoy the work. Most of the grade is contingent on the two tests (both open-internet, and with both in class and take home options), but an optional research paper makes the grading structure more even if one of the tests doesn't go well.
Yes, extremely insightful and inspiring
Yes I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in understanding the political foundations of the country and the legal system.

Yes most definitely! A great, challenging course where you will learn a ton about constitutional interpretation and structure. Definitely one of my most enjoyed classes at Yalesuper interesting and very rewarding. I feel like i learned a lot and developed my own critical thinking skills with regard to constitutional interpretation.
Yes, it is unlike any other class I have taken at Yale.

I would recommend this course for anyone and everyone. Do not be scared off by the workload! You can cut corners, and the class is so impactful that I'd suggest people do whatever they need to to take this course.
Yeah, it can be interesting, I guess.
TAKE THIS CLASS
No because Akhil Amar is one of the worst professors I've ever come across at Yale. If it was just the TAs it would be great.
Yes. Important for any American to have a grasp on.
Yes, but only to credit D.

Yeah. Lots of work though. It's really tough to get an A. Just remember, you're being graded by 2nd/3rd year law students at one of the best law schools in the world on subjects they're all well-versed in. Don't take this if you're going for a good grade.

100% without a doubt, no questions asked, oh yes should you take this course. There is a reason it has the reputation it has, so don't be one of the rebels who thinks it's taught poorly and by someone who is "arrogant". Professor Amar is a gem, and, while obviously confident in his knowledge and in himself, he offers students one of the most remarkable opportunities to become an educated citizen. Even if you're not an American, the modalities you learn and the cases you discuss will shape your view of the world and give you amazing insight into how laws affect us daily. Yes there are law snakes in the class, and yes there are people who credit/D it and barely learn anything, but don't let these tropes tramp your style. DO the readings (only the casebook is relevant), GO to section, GO to class, and you'll learn so much. It's that simple. take constitutional law with amar. (drops the mic)
Definitely take this course if you are interested in law.
Wholeheartedly. This class is much more manageable than publicly perceived and was the highlight of my semester. I came to every single class enthusiastic and left with my mind blown.

Would recommend if you're actually willing to put in at least a modicum of work. Taking this course Cr/D allows you to do nearly nothing for most of the semester, than just crunch before the exams to get a passing grade. That might work, but ultimately you won't get much out of the course and it'll largely feel like a waste of time. Without doing even some of the readings or at least attaining a baseline understanding of the cases covered, lecture will be nigh incomprehensible (Amar is good, but his proclivity for tangents clutters his lectures, almost rendering them impenetrable absent a basic familiarity with the case under discussion). Actually investing in the class is far, far more rewarding.  It gives you an actual opportunity to do law, and if you're anything like me, you'll find that immensely enjoyable. The course material is genuinely fascinating, and the exams are fun puzzles. If you put in the work, you'll get something lasting out of the class--both the theory of constitutional law and its application. Both involve copious amounts of history, political science, and analytical thinking. As for the lectures: they vary in quality (inspirational/mind-blowing at best and bewildering at worst), but Professor Amar's contagious enthusiasm and passion is constant. That alone makes them worth attending. Also, and this is THE MOST IMPORTANT aspect of this class, go to section and get a good TA. Your TA will be the one helping you connect the dots, guiding you throughout the course, and grading your exams and paper. Choose your TA wisely. That choice will potentially define your experience. I was very fortunate to get an incredible TA. I doubt I would have loved the course as much as I did without his section. 

So, highly recommended, but only if you aren't afraid from putting in some work.

Yes. Contrary to popular belief, this course isn't really a ton of work. There's a midterm, a short paper, and a final. Don't get caught off guard by the midterm and final, plan out your studying early because there's so much stuff to cover. The readings take a lot of time, but as long as you learn to skim and identify the important parts, it's totally manageable. This was one of my favorite classes at Yale, if not my favorite. Amar shares his very opinionated and well-argued point of view on the history of the Constitution, which made lectures entertaining. I think every American citizen or resident living in the U.S. should make an effort to understand Constitutional law, and this class will help you do that if you put the effort in.
I strongly recommend this course

I would recommend this course to students who are interested in Con Law, or who want to get a better understanding of how to approach analysis of legal texts in general. If you're going to take the class, though, take the section. It's absolutely essential to understanding what you're talking about in class, especially when the speed of the course picks up and Amar starts talking about unrelated topics for much of lecture. However, the tests are fair and fun, the topics are interesting, and if you're okay doing a lot of reading about law, you should do fine. If you know you're interested in law, or even if you want to explore this passion, this is the course for you.
Yes, 100%. Just showing up to lecture will teach you SO much about the Constitution, American history, and events going on in the news. My favorite class at Yale so far.
Yes! Classic course. Amar's lectures can be hard to follow, but the TA-led sections are invaluable.
Absolutely. If you have an interest in constitutional law or just law school in general take this course. Even if you don't plan to go to law school you should take it.
I would recommend this course to any student willing to have little exam prep but is passionate about constitutional history and is enjoys constitutional argumentation
Yes! Super interesting and important given the current political climate. I learned a ton about Constititional Law.

I would really recommend this class! Even if you don't know anything about the constitution, he is such an engaging lecturer and he makes it super interesting! It feels like a course everyone should take, especially if you're even barely considering law school. It could be one of those classes that turns bio majors into polisci majors!! Don't be scared by the increased workload and intellectual difficulty, he really wants to make sure his students learn, so don't be intimidated. He makes himself very accessible to office hours and after class lunches/discussion, so if you are lost you can take advantage of having a leading constitutional/law scholar at your fingertips! I did literally 0 readings and I'm pretty sure I did just fine in the class-- just go to lecture and you'll really be fine!

I would definitely recommend this course. You will start thinking about famous cases and American history from a different perspective once you have the knowledge from this class. Also, section is really interesting for students interested in studying law - you will be challenged to consider your argument very closely in a comfortable environment. But I would recommend keeping up with the readings, even though theyre a lot.

Yes! This is one of those Yale courses you have to take. Before this course, I felt ill-equipped to have an opinion about U.S. politics and government checks and balances, but this course will give you all the history and terminology needed to have one!

Yes! Its a fascinating subject and you will learn a lot about the constitution. Don't be scared off by the significant reading. As long as you attend lecture and go to section, there is really no need to do all of it.

If someone is interested in law or constitutional issues, I would recommend this course as a general introduction into the topics. I did not take section with this course, but I imagine my engagement would have been stronger had I enrolled in section. I have heard from many students who loved the class - I did not love it, but it was okay.

I would recommend this course to another student interested in Constitutional law, but perhaps not if they want to rigorous intro to it. The course seems to meander and I often felt unengaged with the subject matter.

I would recommend this course because it gives you the knowledge and language to understand the Constitution and current Constitutional issues of the past and in our time. If you think you might be interested in law school, this is also a great course to begin to learn about the law and to engage with law students (the TAs).

I would definitely recommend this course to another student because it provides foundational knowledge that will help me to be a better member of my society. The readings are compelling and every lecture was interesting.

I would recommend this course to another student because it puts you outside of your comfort zone but provides enough support to learn about a  really relevant and important topic. It also provides a good introduction to what a law school class is like and what it is like to study the law.
Dont take it for fun. But take it if you think you might be interested in law! Take the section. I could sit in that section for 4 hours a week and not get bored!

If you're interested in attending law school, this is a great feeler course. If you're not pre-law, I would also suggest taking this course because learning about the American constitution/constitutional rights will be valuable no matter your profession.
Yes! Con Law is rigorous, but it is so rewarding and worth it.
I would absolutely recommend this course to everyone.

Yes. I enjoyed lectures, and Amars words will stick in my head. Sections were interesting and well taught (Peter Beck was a fantastic teacher, though this was his last year as a TA. Shop around.). The exams were based on thinking, not memorization: theyre open note/open internet, so you must make legal arguments using the information available. I learned during the exams. If you want to take it CR/D, you can do little to no work. To take it for a grade, go to lecture, read as much as you can (case book first, then Amars ACAB, AUC), pay careful attention in section, and study hard for exams.
